Key Arguments: The bill infringes on freedom of speech by compelling tech companies to censor content that could be labeled as misinformation or disinformation.
There is no clear standard for what constitutes misinformation or disinformation, leading to potential over-censorship.
Historically, ideas that were once unpopular or controversial have later been proven true, suggesting that current 'truths' may also be fallible.
The bill lacks clarity, accountability, and safeguards against misuse of censorship powers.
The exclusion of government-authorized content from censorship is seen as hypocritical and inconsistent.
Main Themes: Historical context of truth and fallibility
Lack of clarity and accountability in the bill
Notable Quotes: This bill tramples on freedom of speech by compelling big tech to silence discussion which – even unintentionally – causes 'harm'.
Humanity has not become infallible since then and people still make mistakes.
The exclusion of government-authorised content from this censorship regime is hypocritical and inconsistent.
